bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1953

div1.p: Hench inquires if it would be possible to determine the cost to the U.S. Army of the entire Yellow Fever Commission, beyond the regular pay of those involved.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1953

opener.dateline:
February 20, 1953 General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California

div1.p:
My over-riding interest in my yellow fever hobby keeps me thinking about it
even in the midst of a life very preoccupied with cortisone and related
matters and I constantly keep pegging away at loose ends to my story. One
of the things I have wanted to sit down and figure out is the cost to the
U. S. Army of the entire Yellow Fever Board expenses beyond that of the
regular pay of those concerned. This should not be too hard and one could
present the conclusion purely for what it is, an intelligent estimate.

I have never had time to do this, or at least to finish it, and wondered if
you would be in the mood to do it for me, completely at your leisure. I would
not want you to take this seriously enough so that it would worry you or tire
you. I should prefer to suggest it as a pleasant little game.

The first sum of course would be the $10,000 which General Wood gave Reed.
This could be broken down to see roughly how much went for the building of
the little shacks, the rental of the Finca San Jose and the allotments to
the volunteers. We know exactly how many volunteers there were, which ones
got yellow fever (at a larger sum), which ones were inoculated but did not
get yellow fever (Did they get the same amount? At the moment I have for-
gotten.). We know the size of the building. We know the lumber was Ameri-
can wood, some of which was “wasted” as it is still there. We could even
figure out roughly the number of cubic feet of wood used in the buildings.
I have an architect friend who could do that easily.

We know the number of trips that Reed made away from Havana to present his
papers (only one from Havana and back for the first paper). We know that
three of the board went to Pinar del Rio. We know the exact dates and
duration of their visits there. Their railroad fare would be the only extra
to the government. One could make an intelligent guess as to the cost of
the laboratory supplies which were expended and not returned to the Army.
Do you know whether General Wood ever gave Reed any more than the original
$10,000?

Would you be inclined to peck away at this little problem? I should like to
put the estimate in my book in the form of a table and of course say that
General Truby has estimated that the conquest of yellow fever cost about
so many dollars, perhaps one of the greatest and most profitable invest-
ments of all time.

Also, I find a curious blank spot in my notes and I don't believe your
book answers them. I don't think I have any figure on Walter Reed's height,
approximate weight, color of hair and eyes nor the same information for the
other members of the board. Would you make a guess on these things? That
would be most helpful. I have meant to ask the Reed family about this but
never remember it when I am with them.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
